conclusion: Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity with respect to time.
In a v-t graph, acceleration is represented by the slope of the graph.
The graph shows the velocity of a particle moving in a straight line as a function of time.
We need to find the acceleration during the time interval from 1 to 3 seconds.
From t = 1 s to t = 3 s, the graph is a straight line.
The straight line indicates constant acceleration during this time interval.
The slope of a straight line is given by the change in the vertical coordinate divided by the change in the horizontal coordinate.
At t1 = 1 s, the velocity is v1 = 2 m/s.
At t2 = 3 s, the velocity is v2 = -2 m/s.
Calculate acceleration: a = (-2 m/s - 2 m/s) / (3 s - 1 s) = -2 m/s².
Negative acceleration indicates velocity is decreasing and reverses direction.
At t = 2 s, the velocity is v = 0 m/s.
Using points (1 s, 2 m/s) and (2 s, 0 m/s), calculate: a = (0 m/s - 2 m/s) / (2 s - 1 s) = -2 m/s².
Using points (2 s, 0 m/s) and (3 s, -2 m/s), calculate: a = (-2 m/s - 0 m/s) / (3 s - 2 s) = -2 m/s².
All calculations confirm constant acceleration of -2 m/s² during 1 to 3 seconds.
